docs.snippet: Seven former N.F.L. players accused the league and the lawyers representing 4,500 retirees of failing to justify how they reached their proposed settlement, which includes uncapped damages for players with severe neurological disorders....
docs.lead_paragraph: Seven former N.F.L. players accused the league and the lawyers representing 4,500 retirees of failing to justify how they reached their proposed settlement, which includes uncapped damages for players with severe neurological disorders.
docs.abstract: Seven former NFL players file objection to proposed settlement with league, accusing NFL and lawyers representing 4,500 retirees of failing to justify settlement details; players say settlement would fail to compensate many retired players, including those showing signs of chronic traumatic encephalopathy; other football items noted.

docs.snippet: Seven former players said the proposed settlement, which includes an uncapped amount of damages for players with severe neurological disorders, would fail to compensate many retirees....
docs.lead_paragraph: Seven former players said the proposed settlement, which includes an uncapped amount of damages for players with severe neurological disorders, would fail to compensate many retirees.

headline.main: Former Players File Objection to Proposed N.F.L. Settlement

docs.snippet: The tournament has not produced the disasters some feared, and many Brazilians who were angry about lavish spending on the event cannot help getting caught up in its spirit....
docs.lead_paragraph: The tournament has not produced the disasters some feared, and many Brazilians who were angry about lavish spending on the event cannot help getting caught up in its spirit.
docs.abstract: Survey conducted by Brazilian research company Datafolha finds that Brazilians are softening in their views of the World Cup, buoyed by series of stunning matches and lack of major problems in hosting of the tournament.

headline.main: Brazil Comes Around as the World Cup Plays On
headline.print_headline: Brazil Comes Around as the Cup Plays On

byline.contributor: Mariana Simões contributed reporting from Rio de Janeiro, and Seth Kugel from Salvador, Brazil.

docs.snippet: Nigeria could be suspended by FIFA after the country's football federation leaders were removed from office and its president was arrested on returning from the World Cup....
docs.lead_paragraph: Nigeria could be suspended by FIFA after the country's football federation leaders were removed from office and its president was arrested on returning from the World Cup.

headline.main: FIFA Warns Nigeria After Football Leader Arrested
headline.print_headline: FIFA Warns Nigeria After Football Leader Arrested

docs.abstract: Lawyers for NCAA file brief with National Labor Relations Board, supporting Northwestern University in its efforts to fend of movement by members of football program to form union; other college sports items noted.

headline.main: Lawyers for N.C.A.A. Show Support for Northwestern

docs.snippet: Rescue workers pulled a body from the wreckage of a collapsed highway overpass in the Brazilian World Cup host city of Belo Horizonte early on Friday, confirming a second death in an accident that has cast a shadow over the football tournament....
docs.lead_paragraph: Rescue workers pulled a body from the wreckage of a collapsed highway overpass in the Brazilian World Cup host city of Belo Horizonte early on Friday, confirming a second death in an accident that has cast a shadow over the football tournament.

headline.main: Second Death Confirmed in Brazil Overpass Collapse
headline.print_headline: Second Death Confirmed in Brazil Overpass Collapse

docs.snippet: HUTTER--Dr. Robert V.P., a renowned pathologist died July 2, surrounded by his wife and children in New Jersey, at 85, after years with Alzheimer's disease. A past president of the American Cancer Society, former chairman of the department of path...
docs.lead_paragraph: HUTTER--Dr. Robert V.P., a renowned pathologist died July 2, surrounded by his wife and children in New Jersey, at 85, after years with Alzheimer's disease. A past president of the American Cancer Society, former chairman of the department of pathology at St. Barnabas Medical Center, former editor-in-chief of the journal Cancer, he shaped cancer prevention strategies nationally and internationally. At the ACS, he helped to launch the society's first nutrition guidelines. He was the rare pathologist sought out by cancer patients for advice and what they got in return was a compassionate expert with sensitivity and honesty. Born May 25th, 1929 in Yonkers, NY, he attended Syracuse University on scholarship, played football for Coach F. Ben Schwartzwalder, graduated from SUNY Health Science Center at Syracuse, did his residency at Yale University and at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, served two years of active duty in the Navy, returned to Memorial, then to Yale and became a tenured professor of pathology at the age of 39. In 1970, he served for three years as chairman of pathology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and subsequently moved to St. Barnabas. He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Lauterbach, son Andrew (Barbara), daughters Randi (Stuart) and Edie, and ten grandchildren.

docs.snippet: On July 5 in World Cup history: Paolo Rossi's hat trick helps Italy beat Brazil in Barcelona, Spain, in 1982....
docs.lead_paragraph: On July 5 in World Cup history: Paolo Rossi's hat trick helps Italy beat Brazil in Barcelona, Spain, in 1982.

headline.main: ON THIS DAY: Rossi Breaks Brazil's Hearts in 1982
headline.print_headline: ON THIS DAY: Rossi Breaks Brazil's Hearts in 1982

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTTER, DR. ROBERT V.P.
